metadata.title: Gas-phase dehydration of glycerol over calcined tungsten-modified Zn–Al–O hydrotalcite-type catalysts

Fig. 1 XRD patterns of unmodified (a, c, e) and modified (b, d, f) samples dried at 110°C (a, b), calcined at 450°C (c, d) and 600–1100°C (e), and supported PW(SiW)/Za-2(ZA-2a) samples calcined at 350°C (f). Fig. 2 Change in S BET value for SiW(PW)/ZA-2(ZA-2a) samples with various heteropoly acid content and the temperature of support treatment (a); and pore size distribution for ZA-2 and SiW(PW)/ZA-2 samples (b). Fig. 3 IR spectra of studied samples in the region of absorption of carbonate structures. Fig. 4 Differential IR spectra of CO adsorbed at 10 Torr and −196°C (a) or room temperature (b). Fig. 5 Catalytic properties of Zn–Al oxides (a) and of modified Zn–Al oxides calcined at 450°C (b) reaction conditions: Т r =300°С and contact time of 0.47s. Fig. 6 Influence of the reaction temperature (at fixed contact time of 0.47s) on catalytic properties of the samples: (a) 1 - ZA-2a(450), 2 - ZA-2а(600), 3 - ZA-2a(W)(450), 4 - SiW/ZA-2а(600), 5 - SiW/ZA-2a(450); (b) 1′ - ZA-2(450), 2′ - ZA-2(W)(450), 3′ - SiW/ZA-2(450), 4′ – PW/ZA-2(450). Drawing symbols are the same as in Fig. 5. Fig. 7 Dependence of selectivity toward products on glycerol conversion for SiW/ZA-2a(600) sample. Solid symbols are the data obtained at the reaction temperature of 300°C, open symbols are the data obtained at reaction temperature of 325°C. Fig. 8 Relation between catalytic and acid properties of the samples: 1 - ZA-2a(450), 2 - ZA-2a(600), 3 - ZA-2a(W)(450), 4 - SiW/ZA-2a(600), 5 - SiW/ZA-2a(450). Ivanova a b E.V. Korneeva a V.M. Bondareva a T.S. Glazneva a b ⁎ a Boreskov Institute of Catalysis, Pr. Akademika Lavrentieva, 5, Novosibirsk 630090, Russia Boreskov Institute of Catalysis Pr. Akademika Lavrentieva, 5 Novosibirsk 630090 Russia b Novosibirsk State University, Pirogova str., 2, Novosibirsk 630090, Russia Novosibirsk State University Pirogova str., 2 Novosibirsk 630090 Russia ⁎ Corresponding author at: Boreskov Institute of Catalysis, Pr. Akademika Lavrentieva, 5, Novosibirsk 630090, Russia. Graphical abstract Zinc aluminum (ZA) samples with the ratio of Zn/Al>2 prepared by deposition of a mixed solution of aluminum and zinc nitrates with an aqueous solution of precipitant and varied by the method of modification with tungsten-containing component were characterized by XRD, FTIR, and adsorption methods and tested in the reaction of glycerol dehydration. The properties of samples were studied depending on Zn/Al ratio (ZA-2, ZA-3), the nature of precipitant: NaOH (ZA-2) or NH4OH (ZA-2a), and the method of modification by introducing the [W12O41]10− anion into the interlayer space [ZA-2 (W), ZA-2a (W)] or by deposition of PW (SiW) heteropoly acid on the surface [PW (SiW)/ZA-2 (ZA-2a)]. It was shown that dried ZA-2 sample represented a layered Zn–Al hydroxide with a structure similar to hydrotalcite; ZA-2a and ZA-3 samples contained ZnO in addition to mentioned phase. The modification of ZnAl samples with W-containing component did not change the phase composition but reduced the degree of crystallinity. The thermal treatment of the samples in the interval of 450–600°C promoted the formation of a solid solution based on ZnO which transformed after the calcination at 900°C into mixture of ZnO and ZnAl2O4 phases. It was found that the surface of the studied samples contained both Bronsted (BAS) and Lewis acid sites (LAS). BAS concentration referred to m2 of the surface increased in the row: ZA-2a<ZA-2a(W)<SiW/ZA-2a, while the concentration of LAS decreased in the same row. The correlation between the amount of acrolein formed and BAS content on the sample surface, on the one hand, and between the ratio of acrolein/acetol and BAS/(sumLAS+BAS) ratio, on the other hand, was revealed. Keywords Layered double hydroxides Interlayer anion Acidity Glycerol Dehydration 1 Introduction Nowadays, biodiesels attract a lot of attention worldwide as an important renewable energy source for the replacement of petroleum [1,2]. The increasing demand of biodiesels results in a large excess of glycerol which is a main byproduct of biodiesels production, therefore, the utilization of glycerol is a crucial question for improving the economy of biodiesel production. The multifunctional structure and properties of glycerol give numerous opportunities for chemical and biochemical conversions to produce value-added chemicals. Among the technologies for glycerol conversion, the catalytic dehydration of glycerol is one of the promising routes due to the production of acrolein and hydroxyacetone (acetol) which are the important industrial intermediates for the chemical and agrochemical industries [1,3]. The acidity of the active component of the catalyst strongly affects the catalytic performance in this process to produce acrolein [4]. Especially the catalysts with pronounced Bronsted acidity give a high selectivity toward acrolein [5]. However, the catalysts that showed higher selectivity toward acetol possess both significant Lewis acidity and strong basic sites on their surface [6–9]. The compositions based on layered double Zn–Al hydroxides (LDH) with a general formula of [MII 1−x MIII x (OH)2] x+(A n−) x/n ·mH2O, where MII and MIII are divalent and trivalent cations, x is proportional to the value of MIII/(MII +MIII) molar ratio, and A is the anion with valence of n in the interlayer space, may be of interest for the reaction mentioned above due to the pronounced acid–base properties [10]. It should be noted that the basicity of Zn–Al oxides is about 4 times lower than that of the Mg–Al–oxides [11]. According to Meszaros et al. [12], the conversion of glycerol over 2wt.% Mg–Al–O composition (Mg/Al=2) in the dehydration reaction performed in a batch reactor with vigorous stirring under the reduced pressure (20–25kPa) at 240°C was equal to 50%. The main product was acetol with the selectivity reaching 80%, while the selectivity toward acrolein did not exceed 14%. Therefore, the replacement of Mg to Zn can improve the selectivity toward acrolein due to the lower basicity of Zn–Al oxide. On the other hand, the acid-base and catalytical properties can be tuned by changing the nature of anion in the double Zn–Al hydroxides. It is known [13–15] that the catalysts based on the supported oxides of tungsten or niobium, or phosphotungstic heteropoly acid, which are characterized by high acidity, provide a high yield of acrolein in the glycerol dehydration performed in a flow reactor. However, a fast catalyst carbonization occurs in this case. A pore size of the catalyst was found to be another crucial parameter affecting the activity and selectivity of products. In particular, it was shown that the catalyst with an average pore diameter of 10–15nm provided a higher yield of acrolein when compared to the catalyst with the average pore diameter of less than 10nm [16,17]. In this regard, the compositions based on layered double oxides with the average pore diameter of 10 nm and higher are also of interest [18–20]. The aim of this work was to study the effect of conditions of synthesis and modification of the layered double Zn–Al hydroxides on their structural, textural, acid-base, and catalytic properties in the glycerol dehydration. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation ZnAl samples (ZA) with a molar ratio of Zn/Al≥2 were prepared by precipitation of a mixed aqueous solution of zinc and aluminum nitrates with an aqueous solution of NaOH (2M) or NH4OH (0.7M) at constant pH (8±0.2) and temperature (70°C). Further, the suspension was aged at the same conditions for 3h, and then it was filtrated and washed. The obtained precipitate was dried at 110°C for 18h and calcined at 450 and 600°C for 4h. The individual samples were calcined at 900 and 1100°C. ZnAl sample with a molar ratio of Zn/Al=3 precipitated at pH 10 is denoted as ZA-310. The modification of ZnAl samples (Zn/Al=2) deposited by NaOH (ZA-2 sample) and NH4OH (ZA-2a sample) was performed by tungsten and phosphorus components via two approaches: I — by introducing the anion from solution of ammonium paratungstate (NH4)10(W12O41)·7H2O into the interlayer space at the deposition of mixed solution of zinc and aluminum nitrates. The deposition was performed under vigorous stirring and constant temperature and pH, followed by aging of the suspension, its filtration and washing, drying and calcination, similar to ZA samples. II — by the incipient wetness impregnation of pre-calcined ZnAl support with an alcoholic solution of silica- (SiW-) or phosphotungstic (PW-HPA) acid followed by drying at 110°C and calcination at 350°C for 2h. The catalysts were designated as SiW(PW)/ZA-2(ZA-2a)(Т), where SiW or PW corresponded to phosphotungstic or silicotungstic acid, T was the temperature of calcination of ZA-2 and ZA-2a supports. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Chemical composition of the samples was determined by atomic emission spectroscopy with inductively coupled plasma using an Optima 4300VD PerkinElmer spectrometer. The thermal analysis (TA) was performed on a DTG-60H Shimadzu thermal analyzer in the temperature range of 20–1000°C at a heating rate of 10K/min in air. The sample weight was 0.025g; the accuracy of determination of the weight loss was 0.1%. X-ray diffraction analysis (XRD) was performed using a Siemens D-500 diffractometer with CuKα radiation and a graphite monochromator on a reflected beam. Diffraction patterns were obtained by scanning in 2θ range of 10–70° at a 0.02° step size and 5s step time. Quantitative data on the phase composition were specified using the PCW program [21]. The textural characteristics of the samples were determined from the low-temperature N2 adsorption isotherms registered using a Micromeritics ASAP-2400 instrument. Prior to study, the samples were evacuated at 150°C; the error of the method was 10%. The acid properties of the samples were studied by Infrared (IR) spectroscopy of adsorbed CO. The sample was pressed into a pellet (1×2cm2 in size and 20–40mg in weigh) without a binder, placed in an IR cell, and calcined in air for 1h at 150°C, then evacuated for 1h at 350°C. The adsorption of CO was performed at −196°C and CO pressure of 0.1–10Torr. IR spectra were registered on a Shimadzu FTIR-8300 spectrometer in the range of 400–6000cm−1 with a resolution of 4cm−1 and a number of scans of 100. After recording the spectra with adsorbed CO at −196°C, the sample was heated up to room temperature, and the IR spectrum was registered. After deconvolution of the corresponding IR bands into individual Gauss components, the concentrations of various sites were determined from the integral intensities of characteristic absorption bands using the integral coefficients of absorption [22]. The catalytic properties of the samples were studied in a flow set-up at atmospheric pressure and a temperature of 300–345°C. The reaction was performed in a glass reactor (outer diameter of 12mm) equipped with a coaxially located thermocouple pocket (outer diameter of 5mm) over the catalyst sample with the fraction of 0.25–0.50mm. The glycerol was dosed from aqueous solution (5wt.%) using a NIS-01R liquid pump. The nitrogen was used as a diluent. The composition of the initial reaction mixture (vol.%) was glycerol:H2O:N2 =3:65:32. The contact time was 0.47±0.01s−1. The reaction products were frozen at −78°C for 1h and then analyzed using a flame ionization detector with a packed column (the length of 1m, an outer diameter of 4mm) filled with a Porapak-Q phase (Supelco Inc., USA) in a temperature-programming mode (heating rate of 16°/min) with heating from 120 to 245°C. The rate of the carrier gas (helium) was 1.8L/h, the evaporator temperature was 270°C, and the detector temperature was 270°C. The conversion of glycerol and the selectivity toward reaction products were calculated as follows: S i = 3 / n i · C i Σ 3 / n i · C i · 100 % where C i is the concentration of i product of the reaction, n is the number of carbon atoms in the product, and C k is the concentration of glycerol in the final reaction mixture. The contact time was calculated according to the equation: , t = V × 3.6 U where V is the amount of the catalyst loaded (ml), U is the flow rate of the reaction mixture (L/h). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Chemical analysis According to chemical analysis data, the experimental Zn/Al ratio in studied samples is close to the calculated one (Table 1 ), except for ZA-3 sample with a much higher value of Zn/Al ratio. The introduction of W-containing component to Zn–Al samples either into the Zn–Al–LDH interlayer space in the form of [W12O41]10− anion or by deposition of PW or SiW heteropoly acid on the surface of calcined Zn–Al–O sample did not result in any substantial redistribution of Zn/Al molar ratio. The mole fraction of W-containing component ranged from 0.19 to 0.35 with respect to aluminum (Table 1). The sodium content in the synthesized samples did not exceed 0.05wt.%. 3.2 Thermal analysis The thermolysis of air-dry unmodified and modified samples from room temperature up to 1000°C is accompanied by the appearance of endoeffects on the DTG and DTA curves in the range of 64–487°C (Table 2 ), while the weight loss is from 35 to 6.5%. The decrease in Zn/Al ratio from 3 to 2 leads to an increase in total weight loss from 27 to 35%. The introduction of [W12O41]10− anion into the interlayer space leads to the same effect, with the total weight loss reduced to 17–20wt.%. The smallest weight loss, as expected, is observed for the sample with SiW heteropoly acid deposited on the calcined support (Table 2). The thermolysis of studied samples is accompanied by endoeffects in the temperature range of 64–128, 176–209, and 230–285°C (Table 2). Seftel et al. [23] showed that the DTA curve of ZnAl sample with Zn/Al=4 contained two endoeffects: the first one (at 40–180°C) corresponded to the removal of physically adsorbed and interlayer water, and the second one (at 210–260°C) corresponded to dehydroxylation of brucite-like layers and to degradation of the interlayer anion. In turn, the thermolysis of ZnAl sample with the same Zn/Al ratio, according to Barahuie at al. [24], was characterized by 3 endoeffects at 88, 234, and 286°C due to the removal of physically adsorbed water, the dehydroxylation of hydroxide layers, and the removal of the charge compensating anions. Therefore, the endoeffects observed in our case (Table 2) also correspond to the processes described above. It can be assumed that the endoeffects at 396–400°C (Table 2) are associated with the dehydration of aluminum hydroxide which was possibly present in the samples in small quantities. For ZA-2(W) and ZA-2a(W) samples containing the [W12O41]10− anion in the interlayer space, these endoeffects are absent. In addition, the modification by the [W12O41]10− anion leads to a shift in temperature of the corresponding effect: to higher temperatures for ZA-2(W) sample and to lower temperatures for ZA-2a (W) sample. The greatest difference in thermolysis is observed for SiW/ZA-2(450) sample. It contains only two endoeffects at 86 and 487°C with the total weight loss of 6.5%. The first endoeffect is due to the removal of physically adsorbed water, the second one is probably related to the formation of WO3. This assumption is indirectly confirmed by the data of Liu et al. [25] showed that the calcination of H4SiW12O40/Al2O3 sample at 550°C led to decomposition of SiW heteropoly acid with the formation of WO3. 3.3 XRD analysis The phase composition of ZnAl samples dried at 110°C is determined by the conditions of sample synthesis and Zn/Al ratio (Fig. 1 ). The peaks observed at 2θ of 10.03, 20.09, and 34.38° in the XRD pattern of ZA-2 sample with Zn/Al≈2 precipitated by NaOH (Fig. 1a) are characteristic for the layered structure of ZnAl–CO3–LDH with Zn/Al=2 [26]. The value of d 003 is 0.79nm (Table 3 ). The replacement of precipitator to NH4OH leads to a shift of peaks in the XRD pattern of ZA-2a sample to 2θ values of 11.7, 23.5, and 34.6° (Fig. 1a), which also belong to the ZnAl-CO3-LDH phase [27]. The d 003 value for ZA-2a sample is 0.759 nm (Table 3). Besides, there are additional peaks in the XRD pattern of ZA-2a sample (Fig. 1a) with position corresponding to the presence of ZnO phase [23]. In turn, the presence of an additional phase of ZnO results in decrease of Zn/Al molar ratio in the structure of layered double hydroxide. With a decrease of Zn2+ fraction in the structure of LDH, the value of positive charge increases, and the value of d 003 decreases. The increase of Zn/Al ratio up to 3 leads to formation of two phases: Zn/Al–CO3–LDH and ZnO (Fig. 1a). The fraction of ZnO increases significantly with a rise in pH of the precipitation and aging from 8 to 10, as can be seen from a comparison of the intensities of 2θ peak at 56.8°. It should be noted that d 003 value for ZA-3 and ZA-310 samples is 0.753 and 0.754nm, respectively (Table 3), which is also due to the presence of ZnO phase. Crystallite size determined by XRD analysis is 7nm for ZA-2 sample and increases up to 50nm for ZA-2a sample, i.e. at the replacement of NaOH precipitant to NH4OH. A similar situation is observed with an increase in pH from 8 to 10: the average crystallite size in ZA-3 sample is 21nm and rises up to 47nm for ZA-310 sample (Table 3). The thermal treatment of ZA-2÷ZA-3 samples at 450°C leads to appearance of peaks in the XRD patterns characteristic for the structure of ZnO (Fig. 1c). The а(ZnO) unit cell parameters change and become as follows: a =0.3251–0.3257nm; c =0.5215–0.5218nm (Table 3). Taking into account the parameters of pure ZnO (a =0.326nm, c =0.522nm) [23], the obtained lowered values of parameters indicate the formation of Zn–Al–O solution since the ionic radius of aluminum is smaller that that of zinc. Similar results were obtained by Miao et al. [28]. The increase in the temperature of treatment of ZA-2 and ZA-2a samples up to 600°C does not change their structure (Fig. 1e). Only the calcination, in particular, of ZA-2 sample at 900 and 1100°C, promotes the change in phase composition (Fig. 1e): besides the peaks relating to the structure of ZnO, the peaks characteristic for the structure of Zn–Al spinel appear in the XRD patterns, and the intensity of these peaks increases with an increase in the temperature of treatment. The а(ZnO) unit cell parameters are as follows: a =0.3259nm, c =0.5219nm. For Zn–Al spinel calcined at 900 and 1000°C, these parameters are 0.8111 and 0.8109nm, respectively. This is practically the same as the tabulated data for ZnO parameters (a =0.326, c =0.522nm) and ZnAl2O4 (a =0.8109nm). ZA-2(W) and ZA-2a(W) samples obtained by introducing the [W12O41]10− anion into the interlayer space (Fig. 1b), are also characterized by a layered structure similar to hydrotalcite. However, the degree of crystallinity is considerably lower when compared with that of unmodified samples. The additional phases are not revealed by XRD analysis. The thermal treatment of ZA-2(W) and ZA-2a(W) samples at 450°C leads to the formation of a solid solution based on ZnO (Fig. 1d), as in the case of the unmodified samples. Besides, a slight halo is observed at 2θ of 40–45° possibly due to the formation of tungsten-containing phase which is difficult to identify. According to the XRD data (Fig. 1f), the deposition of PW or SiW heteropoly acid on the surface of ZA-2(450) and ZA-2a(450) samples does not lead to a change in the phase composition: the main phase of PW(SiW)/ZA-2 and SiW/ZA-2a samples calcined at 350°C is a solid solution based on ZnO. However, we observed a halo at 2θ of 25° which was associated with a Keggin structure of РW or SiW heteropoly acid, since the most intensive peak was 2θ =24.5° (the reflections at 2θ of 10.5°, 20.7°, 24.5° and 34.5° indicating the cubic phase of phosphotungstic acid, JCPDS 50-0304) [14,16]. Thus, the deposited component in PW(SiW)/ZA-2 and SiW/ZA-2a samples containing about 20wt.% of PW or SiW heteropoly acid is presented in a highly dispersed state. 3.4 The textural characteristics The specific surface of unmodified samples dried at 110°C is 40±4m2/g regardless of nature of the precipitant and the pH of precipitation (Table 4 ). The modification of ZnAl samples by tungsten-containing anion introduced into the interlayer space of LDH structure contributes to the increase in S BET of ZA-2(W) and ZA-2а(W) samples (Table 4). The same increase in S BET was observed at introduction of Ti(IV)-complex into the interlayer space of ZnAl-LDH with Zn:Al=2:1 [29]. According to authors' explanation, the incorporation of bigger complex molecules into the LDH layers resulted in the expansion, i.e. the increase in the basal spacing from 0.852 to 1.214nm; as a consequence, the surface area of LDH/Ti(IV)-complex increased from 84 to 134m2/g [29]. The calcination of studied sample at 450°C also leads to an increase in S BET (Table 4). S BET is 91–96 and 113–118m2/g for unmodified and modified samples, respectively. A subsequent increase in the temperature of sample treatment up to 600°C results in decrease in S BET when compared with that of the samples calcined at 450°C (Table 4). Fig. 2 shows the change of S BET value of supported PW(SiW)/ZA-2 and SiW/ZA-2a samples. It can be seen that S BET decreases with increase in temperature of the support treatment, and this decrease is particularly substantial for ZA-2 support in comparison with ZA-2a at a comparable content of heteropoly acid (Fig. 2a). According to the results of low-temperature N2 adsorption (Fig. 2b), ZA-2 and PW(SiW)/ZA-2 samples are characterized by a bimodal distribution of pore sizes. The deposition of PW(SiW) heteropoly acid on the surface of ZA-2 sample results in decrease in the pore volume from 0.20 to 0.15 (0.18)cm3/g and in increase of the average pore diameter from 8.5 to 9.1(10.0)nm. 3.5 The acid properties The IR spectra of the evacuated samples (Fig. 3 ) contain the absorption bands in the region of 1000–1700cm−1 characterizing the stretching vibrations in the carbonate and carboxylate structures. The absorption bands at 1070, 1350, and 1400cm−1 can be attributed to the vibrations in the structure of monodentate carbonate [30]. The band at 1455cm−1 observed for ZA-2a(450) sample characterizes the asymmetric CO3 2− vibrations in the structure of uncoordinated carbonate, while the band at 1600cm−1 can be attributed to the CO vibrations of bidentate carbonate. The band at 1550cm−1 refers to the asymmetric COO- vibrations of monodentate carbonate [30]. The total amount of carbonate–carboxylate structures estimated from the integrated intensity of absorption in the region of 1200–1700–cm−1 is 1500, 1200, and 700μmol/g for ZA-2a(450), SiW/ZA-2a(450), and ZA-2a(W)(450) samples, respectively. For ZA-2a(600) and SiW/ZA-2a(600) samples, it amounts to 1300 and 700μmol/g, respectively. Hence, the total amount of carbonate-carboxylate structures is reduced both at the modification of ZnAl samples by W-containing components and at increase in the temperature of the support treatment. To study the surface acid sites in the samples, the carbon monoxide was used as a probe molecule which formed the complexes with Lewis acid sites (LAS) and Bronsted acid sites (BAS) of the surface [22]. Fig. 4 a shows the IR spectra of CO adsorbed on the samples at −196°C and a pressure of 10 Torr. For all the samples, a broad band with a maximum at 2151–2160cm−1 is observed. This band may contain the contributions from physically adsorbed CO molecules (ν CO =2140–2150cm−1) and CO molecules forming hydrogen bonds with OH groups of weak acidity (ν CO ≈2158cm−1). The position of this band characterizes the adsorption of CO on the OH groups indicating the Bronsted acidity of studied samples. The absorption bands in the region of 2170–2205cm−1 are also present in the IR spectra of adsorbed CO (Fig. 4a), and can be attributed to the adsorption of CO on both Al3+ and Zn2+ cations [22,31]. The absorption bands at 2195–2205cm−1 may characterize the adsorption of CO at tungsten cations [32]. To clarify this assumption, the IR spectra of CO adsorbed on the samples at room temperature and a pressure of 10Torr were registered (Fig. 4b). Indeed, there is a band at 2205cm−1 in the spectrum of ZA-2a(W)(450) sample, which is absent in the spectrum of CO adsorbed on ZA-2a(450) sample (Fig. 4a). This absorption band can be assigned to the CO complexes with W5+ cations appeared as a result of the partial destruction of the interlayer [W12O41]10− anion and possible interaction with the components in amorphous state. The estimated concentration of these complexes is 7, 9, and 40μmol/g for SiW/ZA-2a(600), SiW/ZA-2a(450) and ZA-2a(W)(450) samples, respectively. Thus, the largest concentration of mentioned complexes is formed in the sample prepared by adding the W-containing anion into the interlayer space of ZnAl LDH followed by treatment at 450°C. The concentration of acid sites calculated from the integrated intensities of corresponding absorption bands is shown in Table 5 . According to the results (Table 5), the strength of BAS characterized by the value of proton affinity is 1340–1390kJ/mol. Generally, the OH groups are weakly acidic. The concentration of BAS referred to the specific surface increases in the row (Table 5): ZA-2a(450)<ZA-2a(600)<ZA-2a(W)(450)<SiW/ZA-2a(600)<SiW/ZA-2a(450). The strength of the LAS is characterized by the frequency of adsorbed CO; the stronger the site, the higher the frequency of the band. In this case, the strongest sites are those characterized by the absorption bands at 2196–2203cm−1, but their concentration is lower than that of the weaker LAS (Table 5). The concentration of weak LAS estimated from the integrated intensity of absorption bands at 2168–2170 and 2179–2185cm−1 increases in the row: SiW/ZA-2a(450)<SiW/ZA-2a(600)<ZA-2a(450)<ZA-2a(600)<ZA-2a(W)(450). The same sequence is observed for the total concentration of the LAS referred to the specific surface. The analysis of the mentioned rows of changes in the concentration BAS and LAS shows that SiW/ZA-2a(450) sample contains the highest concentration of BAS and the lowest concentration of LAS. In accordance with the literature data, the obtained dependencies of changes on the acid properties of the samples should effect their activity and selectivity in the dehydration of glycerol. 3.6 Catalytic properties The main products of the gas-phase conversion of glycerol over the layered binary and modified Zn–Al oxides are acetol and acrolein formed during the dehydration with removal of one or two water molecules, respectively. The byproducts (acetaldehyde, ethanol, acetic acid, allyl alcohol, acetone, ethylene glycol, propylene glycol, 2,3-butanedione, and hydroxybutanon) are formed in minor amounts; therefore, we will present only the total selectivity toward these products (Sothers). Fig. 5 a shows the conversion of glycerol and the selectivity toward the products of reaction performed at 300°C over unmodified layered binary Zn–Al oxides synthesized in various conditions. It can be seen that the values of glycerol conversion are low (2–4%), and glycerol dehydration preferably proceeds with formation of acetol (Fig. 5a); the selectivity toward acetol reaches 70–80%. The data analysis shows (Fig. 5a) that the fraction of acrolein in dehydration products increases for ZA-2a sample precipitated with ammonia instead of sodium hydroxide (ZA-2 sample). The suppression of the formation of by-products is also observed, and it becomes more distinct with increase in the temperature of the support treatment. The catalytic characteristics of modified ZA-2(W), ZA-2a(W), SiW/ZA-2, and SiW/ZA-2a samples calcined at 450°C are shown in Fig. 5b. According to obtained results (Fig. 5b), the modified samples provide an increase in the activity and selectivity toward acrolein regardless of the conditions of binary Zn-Al oxide synthesis and the way of introducing the tungsten-containing component. Other things being equal, higher values of glycerol conversion and selectivity toward acrolein are observed for the samples based on ZnAl-LDH precipitated with ammonia. Thus, the conversion of glycerol increases from 2 to 6% when comparing ZA-2(450) sample with ZA-2(W)(450) modified by tungstate ion introduced into the interlayer space of ZA-2, and from 2 to 27% when comparing ZA-2(450) sample with SiW/ZA-2 obtained by deposition of SiW heteropoly acid on ZA-2(450). The observed increase in selectivity toward acrolein from 7 to 31 and 57% for ZA-2(450), ZA-2(W)(450), and SiW/ZA-2 samples, respectively, leads to an increase in ratio of acrolein/acetol from 0.05 to 0.6 and 1.1, respectively. For similar ZA-2a(450), ZA-2a(W)(450), and SiW/ZA-2a samples, the conversion increases from 4 to 26 and 63%, and the ratio of acrolein/acetol increases from 0.2 to 1.2 and 2.6, respectively. Therefore, SiW/ZA-2a catalyst provides the highest ratio of acrolein/acetol among the studied catalysts. The increase in the temperature of glycerol dehydration for all studied samples leads to the consistent increase in the conversion (Fig. 6 ). The selectivity toward acrolein slightly increases and the selectivity toward acetol decreases resulting in the growth of acrolein/acetol ratio. The selectivity toward byproducts increases together with dropping the selectivity toward acetol. The observed dependencies of the selectivity may indicate an increase in the fraction of secondary processes that occur both at the conversion of glycerol and at the conversion of acetol. To reveal the pathways of the reaction products formation, a dependence of the selectivity of corresponding product on the conversion of glycerol was studied, since the selectivity of the reaction products at low conversions characterize the fraction of products formed directly from glycerol via parallel routes. In turn, the selectivity at high conversions indicates the transformation of products via consecutive secondary routes. Fig. 7 shows that an increase in the reaction temperature for SiW/ZA-2a(600) sample leads to an increase in the fraction of acrolein at low glycerol conversion, while the fraction of by-products formed from glycerol remains unchanged. At the same time, an increase in temperature promotes the conversion of acetol, as evidenced by the decrease in the selectivity toward acetol and the simultaneous increase in the selectivity toward by-products at 325°C and the glycerol conversion of 60% and higher. Thus, the conversion of glycerol over layered binary modified Zn–Al oxides can be represented by a following consecutive-parallel scheme: As noted above (Fig. 5), the introduction of the tungsten component of acid character in the binary Zn–Al oxide increases the activity of the samples and their selectivity toward acrolein. This effect appears explicitly at the modification of Zn–Al oxide with SiW heteropoly acid which is characterized by high Bronsted acidity [33]. The correlation between the amount of acrolein and the content of BAS on the surface of samples is confirmed by results shown in Fig. 8 : the acrolein concentration increases with the rise in BAS content, whereas the ratio of acrolein/acetol increases with the rise in ratio of BAS/(ΣLAS+BAS). Therefore, the higher the fraction of BAS in the total amount of acid sites, the larger the ratio of acrolein/acetol. It should be noted that the amount of acrolein (A) accumulated for 1h and referred to 1m2 of the catalyst surface was calculated according to the formula: A = C × U P × S BET , where C is the concentration of acrolein (mol/L), U is the flow rate of the reaction mixture (L/h), P is the sample weight (g), S BET is the specific surface area (m2/g). The observed correlations are consistent with the published data [34] on the mechanism of glycerol dehydration and acrolein and acetol formation with participation of Bronsted and Lewis acid sites, respectively. 4 Conclusions The study of influence of preparation conditions for ZnAl samples with Zn/Al≥2 showed that dried samples represent the layered ZnAl–CO3–LDH with a hydrotalcite-like structure. The interlayer d 003 distance is 0.79 and 0.75nm for the samples with Zn/Al=2 deposited by NaOH and NH4OH, respectively. For the sample with Zn/Al=3 deposited by NaOH, d 003 is 0.75nm. Lower values of d 003 are due to the fact that these samples contain ZnO in addition to the phase of hydrotalcite structure. The presence of ZnO leads to a decrease in Zn/Al molar ratio in hydrotalcite structure, thereby increasing the value of the positive charge providing the decrease in d 003. Modified ZnAl samples prepared either by introducing the [W12O41]10− anion into the interlayer space of LDH, or by deposition of PW(SiW) heteropoly acid on its surface, are also characterized by a layered hydrotalcite-like structure; however, the degree of crystallinity is considerably lower when compared with unmodified samples. The thermal treatment of the samples at 450 or 600°C leads to the formation of a solid solution based on ZnO. Only calcination of unmodified samples at 900–1100°C leads to the formation of a mixture of ZnO and ZnAl2O4 with the lattice parameters being almost the same as the tabulated values. These structural changes affect the texture and surface acid-base properties of the samples. S BET value of the dried unmodified samples is 40±4m2/g, regardless of pH and the nature of precipitant. The modification of ZnAl samples with tungsten component introduced into the interlayer space of LDH structure increases S BET, while the deposition of tungsten component as PW(SiW) heteropoly acid on the surface results in decrease in S BET. The thermal treatment of ZnAl samples at 450°C is accompanied by an increase in S BET which reaches 91–96m2/g for the unmodified samples and 113–118m2/g for modified ones. ZA-2 and PW(SiW)/ZA-2 samples are characterized by a bimodal pore size distribution. The deposition of PW(SiW) heteropoly acid on the surface of ZA-2 results in reduction of pore volume from 0.20 to 0.15 (0.18)cm3/g and in increase of the average pore diameter from 8.5 to 9.1(10.0)nm. Bronsted and Lewis acid sites are present on the surface of ZnAl samples. The concentration of BAS referred to the specific surface increases in the row: ZA-2a(450)≈ZA-2a(600)<ZA-2a(W)(450)<SiW/ZA-2a(600)<SiW/ZA-2a(450). Therefore, the introduction of tungsten-containing component into ZnAl samples, especially in the form of SiW heteropoly acid, provides the increase in BAS concentration. The concentration of LAS referred to the specific surface decreases in the same row of catalysts. As expected, the catalytic properties of ZnAl samples in the gas-phase dehydration of glycerol appeared to be dependent on the state of the surface. The main products of the reaction over the modified layered binary Zn–Al oxides are acetol and acrolein formed during the dehydration with removal of one and two water molecules, respectively; the by-products from C2 to C4+ are formed in negligible amounts. The correlation between the amount of acrolein and the BAS concentration on the sample surface, as well as the correlation between the acrolein/acetol ratio and the ratio of BAS/(ΣLAS+BAS) were revealed. coredata.dc:description: Zinc aluminum (ZA) samples with the ratio of Zn/Al>2 prepared by deposition of a mixed solution of aluminum and zinc nitrates with an aqueous solution of precipitant and varied by the method of modification with tungsten-containing component were characterized by XRD, FTIR, and adsorption methods and tested in the reaction of glycerol dehydration. The properties of samples were studied depending on Zn/Al ratio (ZA-2, ZA-3), the nature of precipitant: NaOH (ZA-2) or NH4OH (ZA-2a), and the method of modification by introducing the [W12O41]10− anion into the interlayer space [ZA-2 (W), ZA-2a (W)] or by deposition of PW (SiW) heteropoly acid on the surface [PW (SiW)/ZA-2 (ZA-2a)]. It was shown that dried ZA-2 sample represented a layered Zn–Al hydroxide with a structure similar to hydrotalcite; ZA-2a and ZA-3 samples contained ZnO in addition to mentioned phase. The modification of ZnAl samples with W-containing component did not change the phase composition but reduced the degree of crystallinity. The thermal treatment of the samples in the interval of 450–600°C promoted the formation of a solid solution based on ZnO which transformed after the calcination at 900°C into mixture of ZnO and ZnAl2O4 phases. It was found that the surface of the studied samples contained both Bronsted (BAS) and Lewis acid sites (LAS). BAS concentration referred to m2 of the surface increased in the row: ZA-2a<ZA-2a(W)<SiW/ZA-2a, while the concentration of LAS decreased in the same row. The correlation between the amount of acrolein formed and BAS content on the sample surface, on the one hand, and between the ratio of acrolein/acetol and BAS/(sumLAS+BAS) ratio, on the other hand, was revealed.

coredata.dc:title: Gas-phase dehydration of glycerol over calcined tungsten-modified Zn–Al–O hydrotalcite-type catalysts
